roleset.name: to pay
roleset.note: FORK_OVER-V NOTES: Frames file for 'fork' based on survey of sentences in the WSJ corpus. Comparison with 'pay'. (from fork.01-v predicate notes)

example.name: passive
example.text: The lawsuit alleges that an inventory of Pinkerton 's memorabilia disclosed that [one of the watches]-1 had n't been forked [*-1]over by American Brands .

example.name: with Arg3
example.text: Two Los Angeles radio stations initiated Red Cross donation campaigns , and one Los Angeles bank manager forked over $ 150,000 [*U*] of his own money for relief purposes , the Red Cross said [0][*T*-1] .

example.name: with Arg1 and Arg3
example.text: He noted that unlike an employee stock ownership plan , where a company usually borrows money from third party lenders [*] to buy stock that it sets [*T*-1]aside [*] to award employees over time [*T*-2] , here employees-3 had [*-3] to fork out their own cash for the stock .

roleset.name: branching, forking, dividing
roleset.note: FORK-N NOTES: Added by Julia based on WN sense 2. No VNcls. (from fork.01-n)

roles.note: If you can't replace 'fork' with 'forking', it's probably not an event. Watch out for non-eventive usages describing a location, a section or a utensil. (from fork.01-n)

example.name: NOT EVENTIVE! Call .YY!
example.text: Sometimes, it is necessary to remove a fork of your private repository because someone has left your organization or stopped contributing to a project.

example.name: NOT EVENTIVE! Call .YY!
example.text: Hell , I 'd try anything once , but if I change my mind , bet Andrew Zimmer would be right there with a fork and a knife !

example.name: arg1, MNR
example.text: The king faintly opened his left eye, the verdant pupils, peering out beneath his lashes as the sudden fork of the song.
